description: From Middle English mouth, from Old English m≈´√æ, from Proto-West Germanic *mun√æ, from Proto-Germanic *mun√æaz (‚Äúmouth‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *ment- (‚Äúto chew; jaw, mouth‚Äù).

Cognate with Scots mooth (‚Äúmouth‚Äù), North Frisian m√ºd, m√ºth, m√ºss (‚Äúmouth‚Äù), West Frisian m√ªn (‚Äúmouth‚Äù), Dutch mond (‚Äúmouth‚Äù), muide (‚Äúriver mouth‚Äù) and mui (‚Äúriptide‚Äù), German Mund (‚Äúmouth‚Äù), Swedish mun (‚Äúmouth‚Äù), Norwegian munn (‚Äúmouth‚Äù), Faroese mu√∞ur, munnur (‚Äúmouth‚Äù), Icelandic munnur (‚Äúmouth‚Äù), Gothic êåºêåøêåΩêå∏êçÉ (mun√æs, ‚Äúmouth‚Äù), Latin mentum (‚Äúchin‚Äù) and mand≈ç (‚Äúto chew‚Äù), Ancient Greek ŒºŒ¨œÉœÑŒ±Œæ (m√°stax, ‚Äújaws, mouth‚Äù) and ŒºŒ±œÉŒ¨ŒøŒºŒ±Œπ (mas√°omai, ‚Äúto chew‚Äù), Albanian mjek√´r (‚Äúchin, beard‚Äù), Welsh mant (‚Äújawbone‚Äù), Hittite [script needed] (mƒìni, ‚Äúchin‚Äù).
The verb is from Middle English mouthen, from the noun.

entries.meaning: (anatomy) The opening of a creature through which food is ingested.
examples: "Open your mouth and say 'aah'," directed the doctor.

entries.meaning: The end of a river out of which water flows into a sea or other large body of water.
examples: The mouth of the river is a good place to go birdwatching in spring and autumn.

entries.meaning: An outlet, aperture or orifice.
(slang) A loud or overly talkative person.
examples: My kid sister is a real mouth; she never shuts up.

entries.meaning: (saddlery) The crosspiece of a bridle bit, which enters the mouth of an animal.
(obsolete) A principal speaker; one who utters the common opinion; a mouthpiece.
examples: Every coffeehouse has some particular statesman belonging to it, who is the mouth of the street where he lives.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Speech; language; testimony.
examples: that in the mouth of two or three witnesses every word may be established

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A wry face; a grimace; a mow.

verbs.description: mouth (third-person singular simple present mouths, present participle mouthing, simple past and past participle mouthed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To speak; to utter.
examples: He mouthed his opinions on the subject at the meeting.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make the actions of speech, without producing sound.
examples: The prompter mouthed the words to the actor, who had forgotten them.

entries.meaning: To form with the mouth.
(transitive, intransitive) To utter with a voice that is overly loud or swelling.
To exit at a mouth (such as a river mouth)
(transitive) To pick up or handle with the lips or mouth, but not chew or swallow.
examples: The fish mouthed the lure, but didn't bite.

entries.meaning: To take into the mouth; to seize or grind with the mouth or teeth; to chew; to devour.
To form or cleanse with the mouth; to lick, as a bear licks her cub.
To carry in the mouth.
(obsolete) To make mouths at
To form a mouth or opening in.
(sheep husbandry) To examine the teeth of.
